news_summary: The EU-funded show 'The Anger of the Letters' in Tirana promotes inclusivity by engaging children with visual impairments.
news_summary_fr: À Tirana, le spectacle "La colère des lettres", financé par l'UE, promeut l'inclusion en faisant participer les enfants souffrant de déficiences visuelles.
news_summary_es: El espectáculo financiado por la UE "La cólera de las letras", en Tirana, fomenta la inclusión mediante la participación de niños con deficiencias visuales.

articles.title: The show ‘The Anger of the Letters’ funded by the EU, also for children who cannot see in Tirana
articles.summary: The show comes as a joint initiative of two projects supported by EU4Culture, "Heritage Puppets" and "ANNEX Labs".
articles.content:
The show comes as a joint initiative of two projects supported by EU4Culture, “Heritage Puppets” and “ANNEX Labs”.

For the first time in Albania, children who are visually impaired had the opportunity to experience a theater performance up close, touching the set design and puppets, meeting the actors, and receiving more information before watching the described performance with audio.

The show “The Anger of Letters,” which had not been staged for 40 years, returned to the National Puppet Theater thanks to the EU4Culture program, funded by the European Union and implemented by UNOPS.

By investing in cultural heritage and opening doors for every child, the European Union makes it possible for lost stories to be told, felt, and lived again.

The premiere filled the Puppet Theater hall with children and parents. The children were excited by a new show with music and puppets, while some adults returned to enjoy the new version of a performance from their childhood.

At the premiere of “The Anger of Letters,” representatives from EUD/UNOPS were also present, as the show comes as a joint initiative of two projects supported by EU4Culture, “The Puppets of Heritage” and “ANNEX Labs.”

The youngest spectators became participants in the show with applause and by dancing in their own way during musical moments.

At the center of the story “The Anger of Letters” are Olsi and Ini, two boys who speak in abbreviations and carelessly. They take pride in having invented a “modern” Albanian, but this angers the letters, which decide to leave one by one from the dictionary, causing the boys to face difficulties and then return to the right path.

In this show, the actors Florian Kokona, Ilia Kaçi, Esmeralda Kame, Ermonela Alikaj, Erdit Asllanaj, Jorida Meta, and Madi Selimi performed.

The Eu4Culture program aims to revive and promote Albania’s rich cultural heritage, contributing to the sustainable social and economic development of the country. (September 22)

This has meaningful social impact by fostering inclusion and cultural participation on a broad scale.
articles.personality_title: Albania’s puppet show returns with special experience for visually impaired children
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – In Albania, a puppet show called “The Anger of Letters” had not been performed for 40 years. It was brought back by a program funded by the European Union called EU4Culture, which supports projects that protect and share Albania’s cultural heritage.

**What happened** – For the first time, children who cannot see well got to enjoy this puppet show in a new way. Before the performance, they could touch the puppets and set, meet the actors, and listen to a special audio description that explained the story. The show’s premiere was full of children and parents, and many people enjoyed the music and puppets together.

**Impact** – This event made theater more accessible to visually impaired children, giving them a chance to experience a live show in a way they never had before. It also revived an important cultural story, helping both children and adults connect with Albania’s traditions. This shows how culture can be shared with everyone, no matter their abilities.

**What's next step** – The EU4Culture program will continue supporting projects like this one to help more people enjoy Albania’s cultural heritage. Future performances may include similar accessible features, making theater welcoming for all children across the country.

**One-sentence takeaway** – An old Albanian puppet show returned with new ways for visually impaired children to experience theater, thanks to EU support promoting culture for everyone.
articles.personality_title_fr: Un spectacle de marionnettes en Albanie adapté aux enfants malvoyants
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte** – En Albanie, un spectacle de marionnettes appelé « La colère des lettres » n’avait pas été joué depuis 40 ans. Il a été remis en scène grâce à un programme financé par l’Union européenne nommé EU4Culture, qui soutient des projets pour protéger et partager le patrimoine culturel albanais.

**Ce qui s’est passé** – Pour la première fois, des enfants malvoyants ont pu profiter de ce spectacle d’une nouvelle manière. Avant la représentation, ils ont pu toucher les marionnettes et le décor, rencontrer les acteurs, et écouter une description audio spéciale qui expliquait l’histoire. La première a rassemblé de nombreux enfants et parents, qui ont apprécié la musique et les marionnettes ensemble.

**Impact** – Cet événement a rendu le théâtre plus accessible aux enfants malvoyants, leur offrant une expérience inédite. Il a aussi fait revivre une histoire culturelle importante, aidant enfants et adultes à se reconnecter avec les traditions albanaises. Cela montre que la culture peut être partagée avec tous, quelles que soient leurs capacités.

**Prochaine étape** – Le programme EU4Culture continuera à soutenir des projets comme celui-ci pour permettre à plus de personnes de profiter du patrimoine culturel albanais. Les futures représentations pourraient inclure des options accessibles similaires, rendant le théâtre accueillant pour tous les enfants du pays.

**Résumé en une phrase** – Un ancien spectacle de marionnettes albanais revient avec des moyens nouveaux pour que les enfants malvoyants puissent vivre le théâtre, grâce au soutien de l’UE qui promeut une culture pour tous.
articles.personality_title_es: Un espectáculo de marionetas en Albania se adapta para niños con discapacidad visual
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto** – En Albania, un espectáculo de marionetas llamado “La ira de las letras” no se había presentado durante 40 años. Fue retomado gracias a un programa financiado por la Unión Europea llamado EU4Culture, que apoya proyectos para proteger y compartir el patrimonio cultural de Albania.

**Qué pasó** – Por primera vez, niños con discapacidad visual pudieron disfrutar este espectáculo de una manera nueva. Antes de la función, tocaron las marionetas y el escenario, conocieron a los actores y escucharon una descripción en audio que explicaba la historia. El estreno reunió a muchos niños y padres, quienes disfrutaron juntos de la música y las marionetas.

**Impacto** – Este evento hizo que el teatro fuera más accesible para niños con discapacidad visual, dándoles una experiencia que antes no tenían. También revivió una historia cultural importante, ayudando a niños y adultos a conectarse con las tradiciones de Albania. Esto muestra que la cultura puede ser compartida con todos, sin importar sus capacidades.

**Próximo paso** – El programa EU4Culture seguirá apoyando proyectos como este para que más personas puedan disfrutar del patrimonio cultural de Albania. Las futuras presentaciones podrían incluir características accesibles similares, haciendo el teatro más acogedor para todos los niños del país.

**Resumen en una frase** – Un antiguo espectáculo de marionetas albanés regresó con nuevas formas para que niños con discapacidad visual experimenten el teatro, gracias al apoyo de la UE que promueve la cultura para todos.
